comments.text:
bug 500850 changed nsDOMCSSAttrDeclaration so that there is cycle
element<->nsDOMCSSAttrDeclaration. I don't quite understand why.

Marking UNCONFIRMED, since there can be some reason I don't know about.
comments.raw_text:
bug 500850 changed nsDOMCSSAttrDeclaration so that there is cycle
element<->nsDOMCSSAttrDeclaration. I don't quite understand why.

Marking UNCONFIRMED, since there can be some reason I don't know about.
Hmm.  Offhand, I think keeping the old DropReference stuff would have been OK.  Peter?
comments.text: Hmm.  Offhand, I think keeping the old DropReference stuff would have been OK.  Peter?
comments.author: bzbarsky@mit.edu
comments.creator: bzbarsky@mit.edu

comments.raw_text: We rely on the parent object for the compartment that the wrapper for nsDOMCSSAttrDeclaration lives in. I'm not sure I like getting the wrong compartment if the element happens to go away and we hand out the declaration to script again.
comments.author: peterv@propagandism.org
comments.text: We rely on the parent object for the compartment that the wrapper for nsDOMCSSAttrDeclaration lives in. I'm not sure I like getting the wrong compartment if the element happens to go away and we hand out the declaration to script again.
comments.creator: peterv@propagandism.org

comments.raw_text: I think the question is whether that can happen... How can this declaration be gotten without having a reference to the element?
comments.text: I think the question is whether that can happen... How can this declaration be gotten without having a reference to the element?
